text: Hello ,  please can you help me .I'm really stuck. I drew 3 curves in the same figure using Pycharm but the scale of graduations for the y-axis is really catastrophic. In fact for one of the curves the values are very small whereas for the other curve the values are very large so that the curve whose values are very small is almost not displayed. please help . This is the code:  import numpy as np c1,c2,c3=np.array([0,400],dtype=float),np.array([300,12500],dtype=float),np.array([20,45],dtype=float) mb1,mb2,mb3=np.array([0,18],dtype=float),np.array([0,12.2],dtype=float),np.array([0,1.4],dtype=float) import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.plot(mb1,c1,'s-',markerfacecolor='white',label="Process 1 ") plt.plot(mb2,c2,'s-',markerfacecolor='white',label="Process 2 ") plt.plot(mb3,c3,'s-',markerfacecolor='white',label="Process 3") plt.yticks(c1, c1, color='k') plt.xticks(mb1, mb1, color='k') #ajouter les limites des axes plt.xlim(0.4,20) plt.ylim(20,12500) plt.grid() plt.legend() plt.show() plt.savefig('image.png')

author: @greatsea
text: 'pip install matplotlib' generated all kinds of errors towards the end of the install.  It is amazing to me that in 2016 this issue with windows has not been worked out yet.  Utterly ridiculous!  I've had success with Anaconda a few years ago but dammit i want to just be able to get matplotlib touch and go and import it into IDLE.  Anaconda actually hijacks some of the environment functionality of original python install.  basically it breaks it to some degree.  I applaud the iPython project.  It is fantastic but there has to be a way to make it easier to use Matplotlib on a windows platform that can be setup in a standard Python fashion.
